title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple‚Ä¶
But it is possible you first said green (don‚Äôt worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It‚Äôs a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | ‚Äî | ‚Äî | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get‚Äôs it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. üü™

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I‚Äôll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

title: Can ChatGPT help me open the correct PDF?
text:
Hi everyone,
Welcome to my first post! Today, I‚Äôm looking at ChatGPT‚Äôs ability to do understand the structure of Census data. The data are organized into different PDFs as follows.

Part 1: United States and Geographic Divisions
Part 2: Akron, OH ‚Äì Des Moines, IA
Part 3: Detroit, MI ‚Äì Memphis, TN
Part 4: Miami, FL ‚Äì Salt Lake City, UT
Part 5: San Antonio, TX ‚Äì Youngstown, OH


The task
I was curious if ChatGPT would be able to tell me which section would contain data for Philadelphia.



Not a great start


Inspired by the concept of prewarming or internal retrieval described in Prompt Engineering for Generative AI (Phoenix and Taylor 2024), I decided to ask ChatGPT if it could find a pattern in the file structures. Then, referencing our previous exchange where it discovered the pattern, I would ask it to try the task again.



**Better!


Ok, time for the internal retrieval to shine.



Almost there‚Ä¶



Pros: ChatGPT was able to remember that it had previously found that the files were ordered alphabetically when I started the next prompt with ‚ÄúWith that in mind‚Äù.


Cons:  ChatGPT is not correctly retrieving the order of the alphabet.

After expressing some doubt in the alphabetization, ChatGPT was able to provide me with the correct answer.

And just to be sure, I asked it about a different US city, and it was able to complete the task.



So, could this have been done all in one prompt?
I closed out my current session of ChatGPT and tried to create one prompt that would make ChatGPT do some sort of internal retrieval.
I ended up trying this:

Hi! I have a two part question. These are pdf names that have housing data for various US cities in 1950. * Part 2: Akron, OH ‚Äì Des Moines, IA * Part 3: Detroit, MI ‚Äì Memphis, TN * Part 4: Miami, FL ‚Äì Salt Lake City, UT * Part 5: San Antonio, TX ‚Äì Youngstown, OH


Question 1: Why do you think Akron, OH comes before Des Moines, IA, and Des Moines, IA comes before Detroit, MI? Explain your reasoning. Question 2: Which pdf do you think Philadelphia, PA would be in? Explain your reasoning.`

ChatGPT was able to correctly answer Question 1: saying ‚ÄúThe cities are likely listed in alphabetical order (from A to Z), which is why Akron, OH appears before Des Moines, IA, and Des Moines, IA comes before Detroit, MI‚Äù.
But when it came to Question 2, there was more work still to be done.

Then I thought maybe a three part question would help:

Question 1: Why do you think Akron, OH comes before Des Moines, IA, and Des Moines, IA comes before Detroit, MI? Explain your reasoning. Question 2: Can you please print out the order of the alphabet? Question 3: Which pdf do you think Philadelphia, PA would be in? Explain your reasoning.


Sigh! I will have to try this again some other time once I‚Äôve learned more about prompting strategies.
